Highlights

  • Oracle Approved by IHG Hotels & Resorts as a Property Management Provider (2026-01-29)
    Oracle’s formal approval by IHG Hotels & Resorts marks a critical industry-specific endorsement of Oracle’s cloud platform for property management, validating its ability to scale across a complex, global hospitality network. The announcement underscores Oracle’s persistent focus on vertical solutions, incorporating AI and cloud technology to streamline operations and boost compliance for large enterprise clients.
    Strategically, this move deepens Oracle’s footprint in hospitality, leveraging its cloud suite and AI/automation capabilities to deliver tailored services and tight integration with clients’ operational HCM and finance landscapes. For Workday, this showcases how domain-adapted cloud platforms are gaining traction within major verticals—highlighting a need for even tighter vertical alignment and accelerators to remain competitive in global accounts.
    For Deloitte’s Workday practice, the implication is twofold: first, vertical solutions are becoming table stakes within large sector clients; and second, being able to advise on, activate, and aggressively tailor Workday’s HCM vertical frameworks (e.g., in hospitality, healthcare, or manufacturing) will be vital for both ongoing client satisfaction and successful new pursuits.
    Read more
  • Agents of change: Microsoft outlines driverless AI adoption for Canadian business transformation (2026-01-29)
    Microsoft Canada’s vision for AI-enabled transformation, as articulated in its ‘Agents of Change’ piece, speaks directly to the accelerating trend of enterprises committing to ‘AI-first’ operating models. The publication outlines how Canadian organizations are moving beyond piloting generative and agentic AI, instead embedding these at the heart of value delivery, workforce augmentation, and cross-functional process optimization.
    This is strategically significant for Workday and its ecosystem partners for two reasons: first, it highlights how competitors are shaping a narrative where AI adoption is not merely an add-on but core to business differentiation. Second, the expansion of AI agents as trusted digital coworkers challenges HCM suite vendors (Workday included) to rapidly evolve architectures–particularly for secure, responsible, AI-augmented employee experience and data integrity.
    For Deloitte’s Workday practice, these developments reinforce the need to stay close to AI maturity benchmarks, accelerate AI-focused Workday deployments, and consult clients on responsible, productivity-boosting AI integrations. Co-innovation and ecosystem partnerships will need to be presented as systemic strategies to address Canadian and wider global client needs.
    Read more
  • Microsoft Data Security Index: Secure AI Adoption is Top Priority (2026-01-29)
    Microsoft’s latest Data Security Index reveals that for most large organizations, the secure adoption of AI technologies has become a board-level concern, driven by the dual imperatives of regulatory scrutiny and protecting business-critical data. The report details how IT and business leaders are pivoting investments into AI readiness frameworks, workforce upskilling, and comprehensive controls for GenAI and agentic AI use cases.
    For the Workday ecosystem, this signals an imperative to proactively address governance, security controls, and AI explainability—especially as financial, HR, and operational data intersect in the cloud. The index implies that SaaS HCM leaders like Workday must not only demonstrate robust privacy and compliance by design but also practical enforcement of AI guardrails in live deployments.
    For Deloitte, aligning advisory and implementation services to help clients translate these security needs into ongoing AI adoption—through both Workday suite and partner solutions—will be critical. Embedding secure AI practices can become a strong differentiator for both Deloitte and Workday in increasingly risk-aware client environments.
    Read more

Competitive Watch

  • Oracle: Oracle has secured approval as a property management provider with IHG Hotels & Resorts, reinforcing its vertical market expertise in hospitality while leveraging its cloud-based AI capabilities. This development demonstrates Oracle’s ability to win major reference clients through targeted vertical cloud solutions, underpinned by AI-powered automation and integration. For Workday, the focus should shift toward developing similarly targeted industry solutions and demonstrating rapid time-to-value in hospitality and other regulated sectors. Deloitte’s Workday teams should be ready to articulate and deploy vertical IP to close differentiation gaps in these competitive pursuits.
    Source: https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29
  • Microsoft: Microsoft Canada publicized its ‘Agents of Change’ strategy for AI-driven business transformation, promoting widespread agentic and generative AI adoption across operations. Microsoft’s approach underlines both the growing maturity of AI adoption in the market and the urgency for SaaS vendors (including Workday) to foster enterprise-scale, secure, and practical AI integration. Its positioning of AI as core to transformation increases pressure on Workday to expedite its own AI capabilities, integrations, and industry-focused narratives. Deloitte must continue to advocate for safe, pragmatic AI acceleration for clients while differentiating on responsible adoption and seamless migration.
    Source: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/industry/microsoft-in-business/thought-leadership/2026/01/29/agents-of-change-microsoft-canadas-vision-for-ai-transformation
  • ADP, Dayforce, SAP, ServiceNow: No significant new ecosystem, AI, or HCM launch activity in the past 24 hours. Existing signals underline continued investments in AI-augmented feature updates and marketplace integration but without headline competitive shifts. In the absence of major new launches, Workday and Deloitte teams should continue to monitor rolling updates but use current momentum to strengthen client-facing, AI-enabled value propositions on both innovation and risk management fronts. This period offers an opportunity to deepen client engagement on Workday’s responsible AI, verticalization, and integration stories.

Enablement

  • Vertical Industry HCM Deployment
    Resource: Oracle/IHG Approval news
    90-day outcome: Deloitte Workday practice leaders and solution architects build tailored demo assets and readiness packs for vertical HCM (especially hospitality, healthcare, manufacturing) to proactively engage large enterprise clients and partners.
  • Secure AI and Responsible Adoption
    Resource: Microsoft Data Security Index
    90-day outcome: Develop and socialize client-facing playbooks for AI adoption risk management, leveraging cross-industry practices to guide Workday clients toward responsible, mature AI deployments in HR and finance.
  • AI-First Organizational Change Management
    Resource: Microsoft Agents of Change
    90-day outcome: Launch targeted internal and client education on ‘AI-first’ business models and agentic AI potential, supporting Workday clients who seek to lead versus follow in digital transformation.

Actions for Next Week

  • Engage with key Workday vertical solution owners to review and tailor industry accelerators for hospitality, healthcare, and manufacturing clients.
  • Develop a campaign for risk-aware AI adoption, highlighting Workday’s controls and Deloitte’s advisory offerings to address security, transparency, and compliance.
  • Deliver enablement workshops focused on AI-first organizational transformation with relevant case studies and guidance from Microsoft, Oracle, and sector peers.
  • Prepare competitive positioning materials underscoring Workday’s responsible AI practices for use in upcoming client pursuits.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Risk: Delayed verticalization hampers Workday’s ability to compete for major sector clients adopting AI-augmented cloud suites (hospitality, healthcare, etc.).
    Mitigation: Accelerate investments in vertical-specific solution demos, partner playbooks, and co-innovation with industry-aligned ISVs and GSIs.
  • Risk: Clients may view Workday as lagging on responsible, secure AI adoption compared to leading competitors (Microsoft, Oracle).
    Mitigation: Roll out Deloitte-supported executive briefings and transparency materials on Workday’s AI governance, security, and explainability capabilities tailored for compliance-sensitive clients.

All Sources

  • Oracle Approved by IHG Hotels & Resorts as a Property Management Provider
  • Agents of change: Microsoft Canada's vision for AI transformation
  • Microsoft Data Security Index: Secure AI Adoption

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2026-01-30.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2026-01-29T06:49 to 2026-01-30T06:49); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2026-01-23…2026-01-30; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.

For Workday, this showcases how domain-adapted cloud platforms are gaining traction within major verticals—highlighting a need for even tighter vertical alignment and accelerators to remain competitive in global accounts.<br />\\n    For Deloitte’s Workday practice, the implication is twofold: first, vertical solutions are becoming table stakes within large sector clients; and second, being able to advise on, activate, and aggressively tailor Workday’s HCM vertical frameworks (e.g., in hospitality, healthcare, or manufacturing) will be vital for both ongoing client satisfaction and successful new pursuits.<br />\\n    <a href=\\\"https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29\\\">Read more</a>\\n  </li>\\n  <li><strong>Agents of change: Microsoft outlines driverless AI adoption for Canadian business transformation (2026-01-29)</strong><br />\\n    Microsoft Canada’s vision for AI-enabled transformation, as articulated in its ‘Agents of Change’ piece, speaks directly to the accelerating trend of enterprises committing to ‘AI-first’ operating models. The publication outlines how Canadian organizations are moving beyond piloting generative and agentic AI, instead embedding these at the heart of value delivery, workforce augmentation, and cross-functional process optimization.<br />\\n    This is strategically significant for Workday and its ecosystem partners for two reasons: first, it highlights how competitors are shaping a narrative where AI adoption is not merely an add-on but core to business differentiation. Second, the expansion of AI agents as trusted digital coworkers challenges HCM suite vendors (Workday included) to rapidly evolve architectures–particularly for secure, responsible, AI-augmented employee experience and data integrity.<br />\\n    For Deloitte’s Workday practice, these developments reinforce the need to stay close to AI maturity benchmarks, accelerate AI-focused Workday deployments, and consult clients on responsible, productivity-boosting AI integrations. Co-innovation and ecosystem partnerships will need to be presented as systemic strategies to address Canadian and wider global client needs.<br />\\n    <a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/industry/microsoft-in-business/thought-leadership/2026/01/29/agents-of-change-microsoft-canadas-vision-for-ai-transformation\\\">Read more</a>\\n  </li>\\n  <li><strong>Microsoft Data Security Index: Secure AI Adoption is Top Priority (2026-01-29)</strong><br />\\n    Microsoft’s latest Data Security Index reveals that for most large organizations, the secure adoption of AI technologies has become a board-level concern, driven by the dual imperatives of regulatory scrutiny and protecting business-critical data. The report details how IT and business leaders are pivoting investments into AI readiness frameworks, workforce upskilling, and comprehensive controls for GenAI and agentic AI use cases.<br />\\n    For the Workday ecosystem, this signals an imperative to proactively address governance, security controls, and AI explainability—especially as financial, HR, and operational data intersect in the cloud. The index implies that SaaS HCM leaders like Workday must not only demonstrate robust privacy and compliance by design but also practical enforcement of AI guardrails in live deployments.<br />\\n    For Deloitte, aligning advisory and implementation services to help clients translate these security needs into ongoing AI adoption—through both Workday suite and partner solutions—will be critical. Embedding secure AI practices can become a strong differentiator for both Deloitte and Workday in increasingly risk-aware client environments.<br />\\n    <a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2026/01/29/new-microsoft-data-security-index-report-explores-secure-ai-adoption-to-protect-sensitive-data\\\">Read more</a>\\n  </li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>Competitive Watch</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><strong>Oracle:</strong> Oracle has secured approval as a property management provider with IHG Hotels & Resorts, reinforcing its vertical market expertise in hospitality while leveraging its cloud-based AI capabilities. This development demonstrates Oracle’s ability to win major reference clients through targeted vertical cloud solutions, underpinned by AI-powered automation and integration. For Workday, the focus should shift toward developing similarly targeted industry solutions and demonstrating rapid time-to-value in hospitality and other regulated sectors. Deloitte’s Workday teams should be ready to articulate and deploy vertical IP to close differentiation gaps in these competitive pursuits.<br/>Source: <a href=\\\"https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29\\\">https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29</a>\\n  </li>\\n  <li><strong>Microsoft:</strong> Microsoft Canada publicized its ‘Agents of Change’ strategy for AI-driven business transformation, promoting widespread agentic and generative AI adoption across operations. Microsoft’s approach underlines both the growing maturity of AI adoption in the market and the urgency for SaaS vendors (including Workday) to foster enterprise-scale, secure, and practical AI integration. Its positioning of AI as core to transformation increases pressure on Workday to expedite its own AI capabilities, integrations, and industry-focused narratives. Deloitte must continue to advocate for safe, pragmatic AI acceleration for clients while differentiating on responsible adoption and seamless migration.<br/>Source: <a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/industry/microsoft-in-business/thought-leadership/2026/01/29/agents-of-change-microsoft-canadas-vision-for-ai-transformation\\\">https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/industry/microsoft-in-business/thought-leadership/2026/01/29/agents-of-change-microsoft-canadas-vision-for-ai-transformation</a>\\n  </li>\\n  <li><strong>ADP, Dayforce, SAP, ServiceNow:</strong> No significant new ecosystem, AI, or HCM launch activity in the past 24 hours. Existing signals underline continued investments in AI-augmented feature updates and marketplace integration but without headline competitive shifts. In the absence of major new launches, Workday and Deloitte teams should continue to monitor rolling updates but use current momentum to strengthen client-facing, AI-enabled value propositions on both innovation and risk management fronts. This period offers an opportunity to deepen client engagement on Workday’s responsible AI, verticalization, and integration stories.\\n  </li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>Enablement</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><strong>Vertical Industry HCM Deployment</strong><br/>\\n    Resource: <a href=\\\"https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29\\\">Oracle/IHG Approval news</a><br/>\\n    90-day outcome: Deloitte Workday practice leaders and solution architects build tailored demo assets and readiness packs for vertical HCM (especially hospitality, healthcare, manufacturing) to proactively engage large enterprise clients and partners.\\n  </li>\\n  <li><strong>Secure AI and Responsible Adoption</strong><br/>\\n    Resource: <a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2026/01/29/new-microsoft-data-security-index-report-explores-secure-ai-adoption-to-protect-sensitive-data\\\">Microsoft Data Security Index</a><br/> 90-day outcome: Develop and socialize client-facing playbooks for AI adoption risk management, leveraging cross-industry practices to guide Workday clients toward responsible, mature AI deployments in HR and finance.\\n  </li>\\n  <li><strong>AI-First Organizational Change Management</strong><br/>\\n    Resource: <a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/industry/microsoft-in-business/thought-leadership/2026/01/29/agents-of-change-microsoft-canadas-vision-for-ai-transformation\\\">Microsoft Agents of Change</a><br/>\\n    90-day outcome: Launch targeted internal and client education on ‘AI-first’ business models and agentic AI potential, supporting Workday clients who seek to lead versus follow in digital transformation.\\n  </li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>Actions for Next Week</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li>Engage with key Workday vertical solution owners to review and tailor industry accelerators for hospitality, healthcare, and manufacturing clients.</li>\\n  <li>Develop a campaign for risk-aware AI adoption, highlighting Workday’s controls and Deloitte’s advisory offerings to address security, transparency, and compliance.</li>\\n  <li>Deliver enablement workshops focused on AI-first organizational transformation with relevant case studies and guidance from Microsoft, Oracle, and sector peers.</li>\\n  <li>Prepare competitive positioning materials underscoring Workday’s responsible AI practices for use in upcoming client pursuits.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>Risks & Mitigations</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><strong>Risk:</strong> Delayed verticalization hampers Workday’s ability to compete for major sector clients adopting AI-augmented cloud suites (hospitality, healthcare, etc.).<br/>\\n      <strong>Mitigation:</strong> Accelerate investments in vertical-specific solution demos, partner playbooks, and co-innovation with industry-aligned ISVs and GSIs.</li>\\n  <li><strong>Risk:</strong> Clients may view Workday as lagging on responsible, secure AI adoption compared to leading competitors (Microsoft, Oracle).<br/>\\n      <strong>Mitigation:</strong> Roll out Deloitte-supported executive briefings and transparency materials on Workday’s AI governance, security, and explainability capabilities tailored for compliance-sensitive clients.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>All Sources</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29\\\">Oracle Approved by IHG Hotels & Resorts as a Property Management Provider</a></li>\\n  <li><a Canada's vision for AI transformation</a></li>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2026/01/29/new-microsoft-data-security-index-report-explores-secure-ai-adoption-to-protect-sensitive-data\\\">Microsoft Data Security Index: Secure AI Adoption</a></li>\\n</ul>\",\n  \"plain_text_body\": \"Highlights\\n- Oracle Approved by IHG Hotels & Resorts as a Property Management Provider (2026-01-29)\\n  Oracle’s formal approval by IHG Hotels & Resorts marks a critical industry-specific endorsement of Oracle’s cloud platform for property management, validating its ability to scale across a complex, global hospitality network. The announcement underscores Oracle’s persistent focus on vertical solutions, incorporating AI and cloud technology to streamline operations and boost compliance for large enterprise clients.\\n  Strategically, this move deepens Oracle’s footprint in hospitality, leveraging its cloud suite and AI/automation capabilities to deliver tailored services and tight integration with clients’ operational HCM and finance landscapes. For Workday, this showcases how domain-adapted cloud platforms are gaining traction within major verticals—highlighting a need for even tighter vertical alignment and accelerators to remain competitive in global accounts.\\n  For Deloitte’s Workday practice, the implication is twofold: first, vertical solutions are becoming table stakes within large sector clients; and second, being able to advise on, activate, and aggressively tailor Workday’s HCM vertical frameworks (e.g., in hospitality, healthcare, or manufacturing) will be vital for both ongoing client satisfaction and successful new pursuits.\\n  Read more: https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29\\n\\n- Agents of change: Microsoft outlines driverless AI adoption for Canadian business transformation (2026-01-29)\\n  Microsoft Canada’s vision for AI-enabled transformation, as articulated in its ‘Agents of Change’ piece, speaks directly to the accelerating trend of enterprises committing to ‘AI-first’ operating models. The publication outlines how Canadian organizations are moving beyond piloting generative and agentic AI, instead embedding these at the heart of value delivery, workforce augmentation, and cross-functional process optimization.\\n  This is strategically significant for Workday and its ecosystem partners for two reasons: first, it highlights how competitors are shaping a narrative where AI adoption is not merely an add-on but core to business differentiation. Second, the expansion of AI agents as trusted digital coworkers challenges HCM suite vendors (Workday included) to rapidly evolve architectures–particularly for secure, responsible, AI-augmented employee experience and data integrity.\\n  For Deloitte’s Workday practice, these developments reinforce the need to stay close to AI maturity benchmarks, accelerate AI-focused Workday deployments, and consult clients on responsible, productivity-boosting AI integrations. Co-innovation and ecosystem partnerships will need to be presented as systemic strategies to address Canadian and wider global client needs.\\n  Read more: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/industry/microsoft-in-business/thought-leadership/2026/01/29/agents-of-change-microsoft-canadas-vision-for-ai-transformation\\n\\n- Microsoft Data Security Index: Secure AI Adoption is Top Priority (2026-01-29)\\n  Microsoft’s latest Data Security Index reveals that for most large organizations, the secure adoption of AI technologies has become a board-level concern, driven by the dual imperatives of regulatory scrutiny and protecting business-critical data. The report details how IT and business leaders are pivoting investments into AI readiness frameworks, workforce upskilling, and comprehensive controls for GenAI and agentic AI use cases.\\n  For the Workday ecosystem, this signals an imperative to proactively address governance, security controls, and AI explainability—especially as financial, HR, and operational data intersect in the cloud. The index implies that SaaS HCM leaders like Workday must not only demonstrate robust privacy and compliance by design but also practical enforcement of AI guardrails in live deployments.\\n  For Deloitte, aligning advisory and implementation services to help clients translate these security needs into ongoing AI adoption—through both Workday suite and partner solutions—will be critical. Embedding secure AI practices can become a strong differentiator for both Deloitte and Workday in increasingly risk-aware client environments.\\n  Read more: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2026/01/29/new-microsoft-data-security-index-report-explores-secure-ai-adoption-to-protect-sensitive-data\\n\\nCompetitive Watch\\n- Oracle: Oracle has secured approval as a property management provider with IHG Hotels & Resorts, reinforcing its vertical market expertise in hospitality while leveraging its cloud-based AI capabilities. This development demonstrates Oracle’s ability to win major reference clients through targeted vertical cloud solutions, underpinned by AI-powered automation and integration. For Workday, the focus should shift toward developing similarly targeted industry solutions and demonstrating rapid time-to-value in hospitality and other regulated sectors. Deloitte’s Workday teams should be ready to articulate and deploy vertical IP to close differentiation gaps in these competitive pursuits. Source: https://www.oracle.com/ca-en/news/announcement/oracle-approved-by-ihg-hotels-and-resorts-as-a-property-management-provider-2026-01-29\\n\\n- Microsoft: Microsoft Canada publicized its ‘Agents of Change’ strategy for AI-driven business transformation, promoting widespread agentic and generative AI adoption across operations. Microsoft’s approach underlines both the growing maturity of AI adoption in the market and the urgency for SaaS vendors (including Workday) to foster enterprise-scale, secure, and practical AI integration. Its positioning of AI as core to transformation increases pressure on Workday to expedite its own AI capabilities, integrations, and industry-focused narratives. Deloitte must continue to advocate for safe, pragmatic AI acceleration for clients while differentiating on responsible adoption and seamless migration. Source: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/industry/microsoft-in-business/thought-leadership/2026/01/29/agents-of-change-microsoft-canadas-vision-for-ai-transformation\\n\\n- ADP, Dayforce, SAP, ServiceNow: No significant new ecosystem, AI, or HCM launch activity in the past 24 hours.       "url": "https://www.workday.com/en-ch/resources/comparison/why-workday-hcm-is-different.html",
      "title": "A More Reliable HCM Solution | Workday",
      "content": "How does Workday use AI within its platform?\n\nWorkday leverages AI within its platform to improve the productivity and efficiency of HR teams. By tapping into data from more than 65 million users and 629 billion transactions to train AI models, the company offers more than 40 HR use cases powered by AI.     {
      "url": "https://www.pwc.com/us/en/tech-effect/ai-analytics/agentic-ai-workforce-redesign.html",
      "title": "Agentic AI workforce redesign",
      "content": "For many companies, this diamond structure can be a good choice. It can help you manage AI agents at scale, make operations nimbler, and focus people on higher-value work. But it should be a choice, not a default, because for many companies, this diamond structure can carry medium- and long-term risks. [...] If your organization is like most, it’s structured like a pyramid. A small leadership team sits at the top, supported by a larger middle tier of managers and highly trained specialists. Below them is an even larger group of employees, many of whom are recent hires, who focus on routine manual or process work. But since AI agents can take on many entry-level tasks—such as data gathering, processing, and reporting—some companies are reducing the pyramid’s “base.” They’re also repurposing the middle tier to train, oversee, and manage agents. The result is a diamond-shaped structure: a small leadership team, a strong middle layer, and a narrow base of new talent. [...] AI gives HR the opportunity to move beyond process management and become a strategic driver of workforce performance. With the right design, HR can shape how work gets done, how capabilities grow, and how the organization adapts to change. Here’s what CHROs should know:\n\nThe HR business leader can become a business strategist. As new HR generalist roles—like HR operations leads and talent strategists—direct AI agents to handle routine tasks, HRBPs can focus on business outcomes. They can, for example, create bespoke, x-capability focused pods and upskill these pods not by position, but as a team.",
      "score": 0.27872574,
      "raw_content": null
    },

      "url": "https://www.theregister.com/2026/01/30/agnetic_ai_protocols_mcp_utcp_a2a_etc/",
      "title": "Deciphering the alphabet soup of agentic AI protocols",
      "content": "### Domain-specific protocols: UCP, AP2\n\nAlongside protocols for agentic collaboration, client communications, and tool calling, we're also starting to see domain specific protocols for things like e-commerce.\n\nOnce again, it's Google that's leading the charge here. Introduced earlier this month, the Universal Commerce Protocol (UCP) aims to provide a common language for agents to interact with businesses and payment processors. The protocol also works with Google's previously announced Agent Payments Protocol (AP2), which is designed to work with both A2A and MCP servers to enable agent-made payments within a set of predefined guardrails. [...] #### Musk distracts from struggling car biz with fantastical promise to make 1 million humanoid robots a year\n\n#### Google's Project Genie could put even more game developers out of work\n\n#### Agents gone wild! Companies give untrustworthy bots keys to the kingdom\n\n#### Dow Chemical says AI is the element behind 4,500 job cuts\n\nThe Register icon Biting the hand that feeds IT\n\nicon\n\n#### About Us\n\n#### Our Websites\n\n#### Your Privacy\n\nSituation Publishing\n\nCopyright. All rights reserved © 1998–2025\n\nno-js [...] Alongside A2A, Google is working on an Agent to UI protocol, called A2UI. The idea behind the open source protocol is that rather than text-only responses, agents should be able to generate interfaces dynamically on request. For example, if you want help booking a flight, instead of a chat interface, the agent would generate a point and click interface to walk you through the booking.\n\nIt works a bit like this: a request is sent to an agent, which generates messages describing what the UI should look like and sends them back to the client, where they're rendered using established frameworks like Flutter or React. When the user interacts with the interface, new UI elements are generated in response.",

The art of AI orchestration\n\n## Other Sections\n\nPaul Krill [...] With app modernization for C++, GitHub Copilot can reduce toil incurred when adopting newer versions of MSVC, Microsoft said. GitHub Copilot will first examine a project to determine whether it can update its settings to use the latest MSVC version. Microsoft described a three-step process of assessment, planning, and execution that GitHub Copilot follows for app modernization. After updating the project settings, Copilot will do an initial build to assess if there are any issues blocking the upgrade. After confirming the accuracy of the assessment with the user, Copilot will propose solutions to any issues that need to be addressed. Once the user approves the plan, the agent completes a sequence of tasks and validates that its changes resolved the identified problems. If there remains",

[...] Agents interacting with the generated worlds can only perform a limited range of actions for now, and multiple models in the same world have trouble interacting. Genie also has trouble rendering legible text, can't really simulate real-world locations accurately (it's not like Google has a massive collection of 3D maps of notable locations, after all), and it says that agents sometimes lag and don't respond properly to controls.\n\nIn addition, \"A few of the Genie 3 model capabilities we announced in August, such as promptable events that change the world as you explore it, are not yet included in this prototype,\" Google added.",

      "content": "By Riccardo Carlesso • 9-minute read\n\nDevelopers & Practitioners\n\n### Agent Factory Recap: Antigravity and Nano Banana Pro with Remik\n\nBy Vlad Kolesnikov • 4-minute read [...] Developers & Practitioners\n\n# Introducing Google Cloud Vertex AI Extensions for .NET\n\nJanuary 29, 2026\n\n##### Mete Atamel\n\nCloud Developer Advocate\n\nIn October 2024, Microsoft announced the Microsoft.Extensions.AI.Abstractions and Microsoft.Extensions.AI libraries for .NET. These libraries provide the .NET ecosystem with essential abstractions for integrating AI services into .NET applications from various providers such as Open AI, Azure, Google.\n\nToday, we’re happy to announce the Google.Cloud.VertexAI.Extensions library. This is the Vertex AI implementation of Microsoft.Extensions.AI. This library enables .NET developers to integrate Google Gemini models on Vertex AI via the Microsoft.Extensions.AI abstractions. [...] ## What about the Google Gen AI .NET SDK?\n\nAt this point, you might be wondering: Doesn’t Google already have a .NET SDK for Gemini?\n\nYou’re right. There’s the Google Gen AI .NET SDK that we announced back in October 2025. Developers building applications that will only use Google as an AI provider should continue to use the Google Gen AI .NET SDK. Developers building applications that may use different AI providers (Google, OpenAI, Azure ...) will benefit from the Google.Cloud.VertexAI.Extensions library.\n\n## Samples\n\nNow that we understand the context, let’s take a look at some samples. \n\n### Microsoft.Extensions.AI with Ollama\n\nBefore we look into Google.Cloud.VertexAI.Extensions, let’s actually look at the hello world chat sample with Ollama.\n\nLet’s take a look at the details.",

      "url": "https://www.pwc.com/us/en/tech-effect/ai-analytics/agentic-ai-workforce-redesign.html",
      "title": "Agentic AI workforce redesign",
      "content": "In software development, for example, you may no longer need teams of people at work in each stage: generating solution architecture and user stories, creating test cases and test scripts, or troubleshooting, reviewing, and documenting. One experienced software engineer can orchestrate teams of AI agents at work in many or even all stages.\n\nAs they shift from narrow execution to broader responsibility, these engineers—and other specialized, high-value employees like them—can become generalists: working across more processes, making faster decisions, and focusing on bottom-line impact.\n\n## If you're not building your organization with early-career talent, you may be missing out [...] ## Six ways to begin\n\nThe organizations that are successful with AI typically aren’t starting at the edges. They’re starting at the top. Leadership identifies a few high-impact areas for investment, sets a clear strategy, and guides a focused path to value. That can include building a user-friendly orchestration layer to help create and manage workflows and focusing on Responsible AI to enhance performance and grow stakeholder trust.\n\nBut strategy alone likely won't deliver outcomes. Here’s how you can get started.\n\n### Enter the future of work with AI\n\nA new era of agentic work is revolutionizing business\n\nLearn more\n\nLinkedIn icon\n\nShebani Patel\n\nWorkforce Solutions Practice Leader, PwC US\n\nEmail\n\nLinkedIn icon\n\nBrad Herndon\n\nPrincipal, Sales, Service and Marketing, PwC US\n\nEmail [...] New skills and focus can remake the function. HR’s own mix of roles, skills, recruitment, and incentives should evolve too: Skills in people management and policy still matter, but so do new skills in interpreting data, designing experiences, operating across multiple HR domains, and working hand-in-hand with the business.\n\nMore capacity to connect talent to business outcomes. With a new, AI-enabled HR operating model, you can reduce human effort by 40% to 50% across HR. That can free your team to focus on workforce, incentive, succession planning, location strategies, operating model implications, strategies for high-potential employees, and other ways to connect talent to business outcomes.\n\n## Six ways to begin",

    {
      "url": "https://customercenter.wsj.com/todaysPaper/?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqf5juPxts_9qcciLzq41LpyOXBAjOImM5YkfRcec0WcUYYHjKis-Pao&gaa_sig=mhyhG28AmG0KNwFE69tE5_QGXa93LGlSlqRmsW9G8lY4RH4NcieF6O59J5fap4Rt--DPPpNF_4SxIpxLfC3c-A%3D%3D&gaa_ts=693c1d97",
      "title": "Fed Holds Key Interest Rate Steady - WSJ Customer Center",
      "content": "output; it penalizes those in rigidly designed jobs, such as nar-rowly scripted clerical or call-center work. Blanket retraining schemes don’t account for these nuances. Large-scale retraining programs have a mixed record, even when dis-placement is real. When displace-ment is overstated, such programs risk doing harm. They pull workers out of productive roles, subsidize credentials with little demonstrated labor-market value, and signal panic to firms and households alike. That panic can become self-reinforcing: companies delay hiring, workers de-lay investment in firm-specific skills, and productivity-enhancing reorganization slows. The result is a policy-induced drag on growth and adaptation. AI will disrupt labor markets, but disruption isn’t synonymous with de-struction. The danger [...] to be reorga-nized. Technology automates, accel-erates or reduces the cost of specific tasks within a job, allowing employ-ees to spend more time on higher-value activities. As a result, output expands and wages often rise. Soft-ware developers, for instance, rou-tinely use AI tools to generate boiler-plate code, test functions and debug routines—tasks that once consumed hours. The result isn’t fewer develop-ers, but developers producing more-complex systems faster, with demand for experienced talent rising rather than falling. As technology accelerates tasks and reduces costs, companies also create roles that task-based rankings like those from Goldman Sachs and the OECD cannot see. Law firms in-creasingly rely on litigation-support managers and AI-review specialists who oversee [...] initiatives on the premise that mass white-collar layoffs are imminent. Federal workforce initiatives, includ-ing AI-focused retraining grants lay-ered onto existing programs such as the Workforce Innovation and Op-portunity Act, increasingly assume occupational collapse rather than within-job adaptation. But if AI pri-marily augments tasks rather than replaces jobs, this approach misses the mark. Workers don’t need to be rescued from their professions; they need room to adapt within them. This is where retraining could help—but only if it is targeted. While AI won’t destroy occupations in the manner politicians imagine, some workers will adapt more easily than others. AI rewards those with judg-ment, domain knowledge and ma-chine output; it penalizes those in rigidly designed jobs, such",
      "score": 0.027483363,
      "raw_content": null
    }
  ],
  "response_time": 1.8,
  "request_id": "f93399e6-8e00-4437-ae4b-aef0fe0dc03d"
}

Use an export filter for direct ingestion and access the logs through Google Cloud logging. Model Armor logs provide a unified window into AI-specific threats, such as prompt injection and sensitive data leakage.\n\nFor more information, see Model Armor Documentation to Configure Logging.\n\nGoogle SecOps Marketplace\n\nFeature\n\nNew Azure API integration\n\nFeature\n\nOkta: Version 13.0\n\n   The following new action has been added:\n\n       Clear Okta User Session\n\nChange\n\nAzure Active Directory: Version 21.0\n\n   Updated the JSON result example of the following action:\n\n       List Members in The Group [...] Fixed\n\nSupport for table parameters in table-valued functions is restored.\n\nBuildpacks\n\nFeature\n\nThe Python buildpack supports default entrypoint detection for the Agent Development Kit (ADK) framework in General Availability. We also have to consider third-party oversight, and ethics and ensure our people feel empowered to use these tools responsibly.” [...] “We’re bringing AI to our boards on a regular basis,” adds McMahon, “and asking our service providers to present to us on their AI offerings. It carries huge potential in terms of scale and efficiency, but there are operational challenges too, getting people comfortable with it, bringing boards on the journey. People have to be encouraged and trained responsibly, with policies and guardrails. For example, aliasing lets you find IP and MAC\naddresses for a hostname, or job titles and employment status for a user ID.\n\nLike other features in Google Security Operations, aliasing requires data\ningestion and indexing. It includes the following categories:\n\n`Cymbal`\n`tim.smith@cymbal.com`\n\n## Asset aliasing\n\nAsset aliasing links hostnames, IP addresses, MAC addresses, asset IDs, and other\nmetadata. It involves the following steps:\n\n`CS_EDR`\n\n### DHCP indexed fields\n\nGoogle SecOps indexes DHCP records to generate aliases that link\nhostnames, IP addresses, and MAC addresses.\n\nThe following table lists the UDM fields and their corresponding indicator types\nused for asset aliasing:",

      "content": "#### Related Sponsors\n\n##### [[Guide] Why AI Agents Need Real-Time Customer Intelligence](/url/f/3639fe32-595e-491a-a33f-234212357738/)\n\n#### Related Sponsor\n\nRelated sponsor icon/filters:no_upscale()/sponsorship/topic/b4c9039c-eac9-4066-8fab-83c48efcd6cf/snowplow-logo purple-1761807934129.png)\n\nSnowplow enables digital-first companies to turn behavioral data into fuel for real-time advanced analytics, predictive modeling, hyper-personalization, and customer-facing AI agent context. Learn More. [...] After processing hundreds of jobs, the agent develops intuition about patterns: Small datasets with few categories require fewer workstations, while large datasets with many categories need more. The agent remembers every experiment perfectly, never forgets lessons learned, and automatically applies this accumulated wisdom to new workloads, essentially transforming months of expert tuning experience into intelligence that's immediately available, 24/7. Rather than requiring engineers to reconfigure the system every time data characteristics change, the agent becomes smarter with every job it processes. [...] Formally, RL can be described as an AI agent interacting with an environment, sensing its state, taking actions, and receiving rewards as shown in Figure 2. Over time, the agent learns a policy (a mapping from states to actions) that maximizes expected long-term reward.\n\nIn this article, the RL agent observes dataset characteristics, tries different partition counts, measures performance, and gradually builds knowledge about which configurations work best for which data patterns. After repeated executions, the agent develops intuition comparable to that of an experienced engineer and automatically selects the correct number of partitions for different workloads.\n\n/filters:no_upscale()/articles/agent-reinforcement-learning-apache-spark/en/resources/80figure-4-1769432233814.jpg)",

[...] ## Oracle Approved by IHG Hotels & Resorts as a Property Management Provider\n\nOracle OPERA Cloud hospitality platform to enhance efficiency and guest experiences for IHG properties across the America, and EMEAA (Europe, Middle East, Africa, and Asia) regions\n\nIHG\n\nOracle OPERA Cloud hospitality platform has been approved by IHG Hotels & Resorts (IHG) as a cloud-based property management system (PMS) for its estate in the Americas, and EMEAA (Europe, Middle East, Africa, and Asia) regions. With this approval, Oracle joins IHG’s exclusive list of approved property management systems, enabling franchisees and hotel owners to make tech decisions that best suit their individual business needs.       "title": "Ceridian Introduces Dayforce HCM Predictive Analytics",
      "content": "Dayforce HCM is a cloud solution for Payroll, Benefits, Workforce Management, Human Resources, Talent Management, Document Management, and Analytics. Built on a single database with one rule engine, Dayforce HCM enables organizations to find and hire the right people, process pay, manage benefits enrollment, maintain HR records, and schedule staff while monitoring compliance throughout the employee lifecycle. Predictive Analytics allows flight-risk data to be embedded throughout the application for easy access and at no additional cost. [...] ---\n\nPRESS RELEASES\n\n# Ceridian Introduces Dayforce HCM Predictive Analytics\n\nData-driven insights help companies identify flight risks and retain high-performing employees\n\nMedia Inquiries\n\nFor all media inquiries, contact us at mediainquiries@dayforce.com\n\nContact us\n\nMinneapolis, MN\nMay 24, 2017\n\nCeridian, a global human capital management technology company, introduces Predictive Analytics, the latest addition to Dayforce HCM – a single application for human capital management. This new capability applies machine learning algorithms to employee data, giving managers and executives a new tool to evaluate employee flight risk and identify and address reasons contributing to employee turnover. [...] “Dayforce HCM has consistently ranked as the leading Leader in our Human Capital Management Value Matrix,” says Brent Skinner, Principal Analyst at Nucleus Research. “This is thanks to Ceridian’s commitment to innovation as they bring full HCM into a single application, with a single dataset governed by a single rules engine. The addition of Predictive Analytics will give Dayforce users the ability to unlock the power of that single dataset for all of HCM. We expect that users will find this new functionality furthering their ability lower costs, boost productivity, improve employee engagement, and reduce turnover.”\n\nFor more information about Predictive Analytics and the entire Dayforce HCM platform, visit www.ceridian.ca.\n\n## You may also like:\n\nView All\n\n Why Dayforce?",

      "title": "Introducing multi-agent collaboration capability for Amazon Bedrock (preview) | AWS News Blog",
      "content": "Amazon Bedrock Agents manages the collaboration, communication, and task delegation behind the scenes. By enabling agents to work together, you can achieve higher task success rates, accuracy, and enhanced productivity. In internal benchmark testing, multi-agent collaboration has shown marked improvements compared to single-agent systems for handling complex, multi-step tasks. [...] With the fully managed multi-agent collaboration capability on Amazon Bedrock, specialized agents work within their domains of expertise, coordinated by a supervisor agent. The supervisor breaks down requests, delegates tasks, and consolidates outputs into a final response. For example, an investment advisory multi-agent system might include agents specialized in financial data analysis, research, forecasting, and investment recommendations. Similarly, a retail operations multi-agent system could handle demand forecasting, inventory allocation, supply chain coordination, and pricing optimization.       "title": "Amazon Bedrock now supports multi-agent collaboration - AWS",
      "content": "Search\n\n# Amazon Bedrock now supports multi-agent collaboration\n\nToday, AWS announces the general availability (GA) of multi-agent collaboration for Amazon Bedrock, allowing developers to create networks of specialized agents that communicate and coordinate under the guidance of a supervisor agent. This new capability allows you to tackle more intricate, multi-step workflows and scale your AI-driven applications more effectively. [...] Amazon Bedrock multi-agent collaboration GA introduces key enhancements designed to improve scalability, flexibility, and operational efficiency. Inline Agents allow you to dynamically adjust agent roles and behaviors at runtime, making workflows more adaptable as your business needs evolve. With Payload Referencing, supervisor agents can reference linked data instead of embedding it in every request, reducing data transfer, improving response times, and lowering operational costs. Additionally, multi-agent now offers CloudFormation (CFN) and Cloud Development Kit (CDK) support so you can create reusable teams of agents as templates that can be shared across accounts within an organization. [...] This release also introduces agent monitoring and observability features, helping you track, monitor, and optimize agent interactions more efficiently. These features improve debugging and traceability, ensuring better visibility into agent workflows and making troubleshooting easier for developers.\n\nMulti-agent collaboration on Amazon Bedrock is now available in all AWS Regions where Amazon Bedrock is supported. To learn more about this feature and how it can help you build more sophisticated AI applications, see the Amazon Bedrock product page or refer to the documentation for detailed information on getting started.\n\n## Learn\n\n## Resources\n\n## Developers\n\n## Help",

      "title": "AWS brings multi-agent orchestration to Bedrock | VentureBeat",
      "content": "“Using multi-agent collaboration in Amazon Bedrock, customers can get more accurate results by creating and assigning specialized agents for specific steps of a project and accelerate tasks by orchestrating multiple agents working in parallel,” AWS said.\n\nCustomers build their specialized agents on Bedrock, and then make a supervisor or orchestrator agent to help manage the other agents. AWS said the supervisor agent “handles the coordination, like breaking up and routing tasks to the right agents, giving specific agents access to the information they need to complete their work and determining what actions can be processed in parallel.” [...] AWS first introduced agentic capabilities in 2023 with the release of Agents on Bedrock, which offered enterprises a way to start building agents. During its re:Invent event this week, AWS customers like PagerDuty and GitLab announced new agents that let users develop their applications on their platforms and use AWS agents to enhance their workflows.\n\n## Multiple agents becoming the norm [...] All Posts\n\n# AWS brings multi-agent orchestration to Bedrock\n\nEmilia David\n\nAWS is doubling down on AI agents with the announcement of multiagent capabilities on its Amazon Bedrock platform.\n\nDuring his keynote at the AWS re:Invent conference, AWS CEO Matt Garman said customers building agents on Bedrock wanted a means to make agents that work together.",

      "title": "AWS Bedrock: Monitoring agents | Boomi Documentation",
      "content": "# AWS Bedrock: Monitoring agents\n\nThe metrics for the AWS Bedrock agents are currently in Beta mode and can currently display only certain items. You can monitor and access your agents through the Monitoring and Compliance screen.\n\nYou can filter out your AWS Bedrock agents based on Provider, accounts, models, and time frames. By default, the time frame selected is the Last 60 minutes UTC. For more information, read Monitoring and compliance.\n\n## Prerequisites\n\nTo view the metrics for your AWS Bedrock agents, ensure you have Enabled Bedrock Agent metric data access.\n\n## Dimensions and metrics\n\nThe metric ingestion into Agent Control tower from AWS Bedrock is split into two categories:\n\n by Agent ARN and Alias ARN\n by ModelIDs [...] | ModelInvocationServerErrors | OperationOperation, AgentArnOperation, AgentArn, PromptTypeOperation, AgentAliasArnOperation, AgentAliasArn, PromptType | Model invocation server errors for a given operation across all agents and all model IDs, for a given operation across all model IDs, all prompts and a given agent ARN and for a given operation across all models for a given agent ARN and given promptType. |\n| InputTokenCount | OperationOperation, AgentArnOperation, AgentArn, PromptTypeOperation, AgentAliasArnOperation, AgentAliasArn, PromptType | Input token count for a given operation across all agents and all model IDs, for a given operation across all model IDs, all prompts and a given agent ARN and for a given operation across all models for a given agent ARN and given promptType. | [...] Provide Feedback\n\nWas this topic helpful?\n\nYesNo\n\nOn this Page",

With the right design, HR can shape how work gets done, how capabilities grow, and how the organization adapts to change. Here’s what CHROs should know:\n\nThe HR business leader can become a business strategist. As new HR generalist roles—like HR operations leads and talent strategists—direct AI agents to handle routine tasks, HRBPs can focus on business outcomes. They can, for example, create bespoke, x-capability focused pods and upskill these pods not by position, but as a team. [...] AI agents are opening the door to a fundamentally different role for IT. Instead of being the team that responds to business needs, IT can become the team that helps shape them—designing intelligent workflows, managing AI systems, and accelerating innovation. But realizing this opportunity depends on making intentional changes to focus, roles, and structure. Here’s what CIOs should know:\n\n### AI-enabled marketing: Anticipating customer behavior and fostering creativity [...] AI is transforming marketing into a proactive driver of growth. With AI agents handling tasks across content, campaigns, planning, and analytics, marketers can focus on creativity, strategy, and customer connection. In this new model, humans can bring empathy and brand insight while AI delivers precision and scale. Together, they can create faster, more personalized, and more effective experiences with insights and optimization opportunities identified proactively rather than reactively. Examples include intelligent access and segregation controls, real-time integration monitoring, audit and SOX readiness, machine learning for risk assessment and predictive analytics, and ongoing improvement via AI-driven feedback and insights.\n\n##### Consequences of inadequate controls [...] ##### Keeping pace with rising FSI industry challenges\n\nToday’s financial services organizations face increasing pressure to modernize their ERP technology stacks in response to shifting industry demands—including evolving consumer preferences, rapid product innovation using AI and blockchain, and heightened regulatory scrutiny. Banks now accommodate stablecoin payments and deposits, wealth managers use AI for asset management, real estate firms are starting to offer fractional property investments via tokenization, and insurers are leveraging AI for both fraud detection and fee-based risk management. [...] Ironically, the same technologies that can reduce risk—digital transactions, AI, and cloud computing—can also introduce new and sometimes unforeseen vulnerabilities. With the rapid rise of cloud computing, more FSI organizations are migrating on-premises ERP systems to the cloud.1 In the process, they may face challenges specific to the cloud and cloud migration process.       "title": "Agentic AI workforce redesign",
      "content": "AI gives HR the opportunity to move beyond process management and become a strategic driver of workforce performance. With the right design, HR can shape how work gets done, how capabilities grow, and how the organization adapts to change. Here’s what CHROs should know:\n\nThe HR business leader can become a business strategist. As new HR generalist roles—like HR operations leads and talent strategists—direct AI agents to handle routine tasks, HRBPs can focus on business outcomes. They can, for example, create bespoke, x-capability focused pods and upskill these pods not by position, but as a team. [...] New skills and focus can remake the function. HR’s own mix of roles, skills, recruitment, and incentives should evolve too: Skills in people management and policy still matter, but so do new skills in interpreting data, designing experiences, operating across multiple HR domains, and working hand-in-hand with the business.\n\nMore capacity to connect talent to business outcomes. With a new, AI-enabled HR operating model, you can reduce human effort by 40% to 50% across HR. That can free your team to focus on workforce, incentive, succession planning, location strategies, operating model implications, strategies for high-potential employees, and other ways to connect talent to business outcomes.\n\n## Six ways to begin [...] For many companies, this diamond structure can be a good choice. It can help you manage AI agents at scale, make operations nimbler, and focus people on higher-value work. But it should be a choice, not a default, because for many companies, this diamond structure can carry medium- and long-term risks.",

For example, aliasing lets you find IP and MAC\naddresses for a hostname, or job titles and employment status for a user ID.\n\nLike other features in Google Security Operations, aliasing requires data\ningestion and indexing. まとめ：AI×Jiraで開発と運用をつなぐMCP統合\n\nJiraとMCPの統合により、開発・運用チームの連携は新たなステージへ。人間によるコラボレーションとAIによる実行をシームレスに結びつけ、より高速で賢いソフトウェア開発プロセスを実現します。\n\nWorkatoのEnterprise MCPを活用し、セキュリティとスピードを両立したエージェント型AI統合基盤を今すぐ導入しましょう。 \nJiraとMCPの統合により、開発チームと運用チームの働き方は大きく変わります。Jira上での人間によるコラボレーションと、AIによる実行・自動化を橋渡しすることで、より高速で、よりスマートなワークフローを実現できます。\n\n本セットアップガイドを通じて、以下のポイントを学びました。\n\n一方で、MCPサーバーをゼロから構築し、セキュリティやガバナンスを担保しながら運用することは決して簡単ではありません。\n\nそこで有効なのが、Workatoのセキュアで事前構成済みのJira MCPインスタンスです。WorkatoのEnterprise MCPを活用すれば、構築や運用の負担を大幅に削減しながら、エンタープライズグレードのセキュリティとスピードを両立できます。\n\nぜひ今すぐお試しください。エージェント型自動化の取り組みを、即座に次のステージへと加速できます。\n\nWorkato logo\nWorkato logo\n\n#### MCPセキュリティのリスクと対策：全てのチームが知っておくべきこと\n\n1月 30, 2026\n\nRethinking UX with AI Hero\n\n## 急成長するMCPとAgentic AI、見落とせない「セキュリティの落とし穴」 [...] Workatoは、MCPセキュリティとガバナンス分野のリーディング企業として、Enterprise MCPエコシステムを提供しています。安全かつガバナンス対応のMCP運用を目指す企業は、ぜひ詳細をご覧ください。\n\n本記事は、Ali Mannan Tirmiziによって執筆されました。AliはシニアDevOpsマネージャーであり、SaaS分野のコピーライティングを専門としています。電気工学および物理学の学位を持ち、製造業IT、DevOps、ソーシャルインパクト領域において、複数のリーダーシップポジションを歴任してきました。\n\n### Related Articles:\n\n## MCPの3つの階層モデル：エンタープライズで機能するのはどれか\n\nAIと業務システムをつなぐ新たな標準「M…\n\n## Basic MCPとEnterprise MCPの違い：CIOが知っておくべきポイント\n\nCIOが「DIY型MCP」から「ガバナン…\n\n## MCPサーバー構築ガイド：エージェント型AIを動かすステップバイステップチュートリアル\n\nAIアシスタントが本当に「あなたの業務ツ…\n\n“” [...] MCPは、AI（特に大規模言語モデル：LLM）が外部ツールやAPIと連携するための共通言語・標準化レイヤーです。\n\nたとえば、あなたのAIアシスタントに「近くのパデルコートで来週の夕方に予約を取って」と頼むと、カレンダー、天気予報、予約システムなど複数のサービスに同時アクセスする必要があります。\n\n通常であれば、これらを個別に接続する必要がありますが、MCPを介すことで「1つの共通プロトコル」で安全に接続できます。\n\nつまり、MCPはAIの「脳（LLM）」と外部の「ツール群」をつなぐブリッジなのです。\n\n## MCPの仕組み\n\nMCPの概要を理解したところで、次にMCPがどのように機能するのかを見ていきましょう。\n\nMCPは、AIホスト（例：アプリやアシスタント）とMCPサーバー（各種ツール）間で通信を行います。通信は標準化されたメッセージ形式（JSON-RPC）で行われ、双方向にデータをやり取りします。\n\nMCPを利用すれば、AIは動的データにリアルタイムでアクセスし、業務を実行できます。その柔軟性と拡張性こそが、Agentic AIの可能性を広げています。\n\n## MCPに潜む主要なセキュリティリスク\n\nMCPの利便性は高い一方で、構成要素が多くなるほど攻撃面も広がります。特に人間の監視が少ないAI主導のシステムでは、リスクが倍増します。\n\nここでは、代表的な脆弱性とその影響を見ていきます。\n\n### 1. 権限の過剰付与\n\nMCPプロセスは広範なタスクを実行するため、しばしば過剰な権限で実行されるケースがあります。この状態で攻撃を受けると、被害範囲は一気に拡大します。\n\n【対策】最小権限の原則を徹底し、AIに必要最小限の権限のみを付与すること。\n\n### 2. 認証の不備",
      "score": 0.046378206,
      "raw_content": null
    },

      "title": "Workday & HiredScore's Focus on Compliance and Bias Mitigation | Workday US",
      "content": "criterion, weighted more heavily than any other criterion, or overrule conclusions from human decision-making at our customer’s organization. Nonetheless, Workday (and HiredScore, prior to Workday’s acquisition of HiredScore) routinely conducts bias testing of its AI products that have the potential to significantly impact individuals’ economic opportunities. While Workday engaged an external consultant to conduct the bias testing of the Spotlight AI tool using the impact ratio approach as described in the NYC Law, the purpose of this testing is in furtherance of Workday/HiredScore’s commitments to identify and mitigate potential bias. Customers may need to conduct their own evaluation, testing and/or bias audits depending on their legal obligations. [...] HiredScore’s explainable AI outputs report to what extent a candidate’s application matches the job requirements using a simple A, B, C, D system, where A denotes the highest match between a candidate’s application and an employer-defined job requisition. Put another way, the technology acts like a “smart mirror” reflecting back the extent to which candidates fit the job requirements set by the employer. The A, B, C, D scores are never “curved.” This means that if a job requisition has commonly held requirements, there may be many more As and Bs than Cs and Ds. Conversely, if a job requisition has very uncommonly held requirements, there may be many more Cs and Ds than As and Bs, and each candidate will receive a score indicating how they align with the requirements; this score is [...] Designing and building responsible AI that our customers can trust and adopt in line with their legal compliance obligations has been part of HiredScore’s mission statement since the beginning. We take responsible AI very seriously and regularly work with outside experts in AI, data privacy, employment law, and responsible AI to ensure adherence to best practices and the highest standards.\n\n## Overview of HiredScore AI Functionality",
      "score": 0.7031221,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "url": "https://airc.nist.gov/docs/workday-success-story.pdf",
      "title": "Using the AI Risk Management Framework - NIST EEOC says Workday must face claims that AI software is biased Addressing AI bias: a human-centric approach to fairness - EY Judge allows Workday AI bias lawsuit to proceed as collective ... Responsible AI Practices | Workday US Responsible AI: Ensuring T...",
      "content": "When Workday uses an AI tool that we have either developed or procured from a third-“As business leaders begin their AI journey, many are looking for a roadmap for how to develop and use AI in a way that is responsible and innovative. At Workday, we’ve found the NIST AI Risk Management Framework to be a concrete benchmark for mapping, measuring, and managing our approach to AI governance. We believe the Framework will help us maintain our customers’ trust and stay true to our company’s core values as we leverage it to innovate going forward”. Jim Stratton, Chief Technology Officer, Workday party and interacts with end-users, we are an AI deployer. [...] With AI best practices and technical standards continuing to mature, the AI RMF is an essential benchmark for AI developers and deployers. Workday uses the AI RMF to assess and refine our responsible AI practices and to communicate the rigor of our AI governance approach to our enterprise customers. With leaders in the U.S., Europe, Canada, Singapore, and elsewhere taking action to promote trustworthy AI, the AI RMF is a common language to understand the expectations and requirements of AI governance. [...] Building a responsible AI questionnaire to assess the third-party AI tools that Workday procures from other AI developers. By evaluating various aspects of AI development, implementation, and usage, this questionnaire helps Workday align third-party tools with our ethics principles and risk management priorities.\nWith AI legal requirements, best practices, and technical standards maturing, Workday will continue using the AI RMF as a reference point for how we assess, refine, and strengthen our approach to AI governance.",

      "title": "Oracle Cloud HCM vs. Workday: 5 things to know | oraclehcm",
      "content": "Given that Workday’s 24 R2 release is scheduled for September 2024, it should just barely make its own timeline.\n\nMeanwhile, Oracle Cloud HCM made a clear announcement regarding its generative AI plans and use cases in June 2023. As of its first release in 2024, Oracle Cloud HCM customers have had access to embedded generative AI functionality that help customers improve decision making and enhance the employee experience. These include knowledgebase articles, job postings, performance feedback and development tips, and review summaries. It also includes many use cases that Workday has not announced on its roadmap, like a candidate experience summary, job category landing pages, and job match explanations. [...] Then co-CEO Carl Eschenbach first discussed preliminary plans for generative AI in March 2023. Workday’s generative AI use cases were clarified at Workday Rising in September 2023, talking about functionality such as job descriptions and employee growth plans. Plans for availability were set for 6-12 months from the event, or between March and September 2024. As of March 2024, Workday confirmed that there were three HCM use cases in an early adopter program as of its 24 R1 release, with none scheduled for general availability until the 24 R2 release or later. Workday subsequently put a fourth HCM use case into early adopter program during its DevCon 2024 event, with no clear plans for general availability. [...] Overall, Workday only has 25 generative AI use cases on its roadmap, while Oracle Fusion Applications have 50+ embedded use cases.\n\nThe innovation comparison is substantial.       "url": "http://mckinsey.com/capabilities/tech-and-ai/our-insights/superagency-in-the-workplace-empowering-people-to-unlock-ais-full-potential-at-work",
      "title": "AI in the workplace: A report for 2025 | McKinsey",
      "content": "In _Superagency_, Hoffman argues that new risks naturally accompany new capabilities—meaning they should be managed but not necessarily eliminated.15 Reid Hoffman and Greg Beato, _Superagency: What Could Possibly Go Right with Our AI Future_, Authors Equity, January 28, 2025. Leaders need to contend with external threats, such as infringement on intellectual property (IP), AI-enabled malware, and internal threats that arise from the AI adoption process. The first step in building fit-for-purpose risk managementis to launch a comprehensive assessment to identify potential vulnerabilities in each of a company’s businesses. Leaders can then establish a robust governance structure, implement real-time monitoring and control mechanisms, and ensure continuous training and adherence to [...] Achieving AI superagency in the workplace is not simply about mastering technology. It is every bit as much about supporting people, creating processes, and managing governance. The next chapters explore the nontechnological factors that will help shape the deployment of AI in the workplace.\n\nChapter 2 [...] Beyond LLMs, other forms of AI and machine learning (ML) are improving explainability, allowing the outputs of models that support consequential decisions (for example, credit risk assessment) to be traced back to the data that informed them. In this way, critical systems can be tested and monitored on a near-constant basis for bias and other everyday harms that arise from model drift and shifting data inputs, which happens even in systems that were well calibrated before deployment.\n\nAll of this is crucial for detecting errors and ensuring compliance with regulations and company policies. Companies have improved explainability practicesand built necessary checks and balances, but they must be prepared to evolve continuously to keep up with growing model capabilities.",

      "url": "https://www.deloitte.com/lu/en/Industries/investment-management/blogs/future-asset-management.html",
      "title": "The future of asset management",
      "content": "“We’re bringing AI to our boards on a regular basis,” adds McMahon, “and asking our service providers to present to us on their AI offerings. It carries huge potential in terms of scale and efficiency, but there are operational challenges too, getting people comfortable with it, bringing boards on the journey. People have to be encouraged and trained responsibly, with policies and guardrails. But the potential is extraordinary.”\n\n“AI has the power to enhance human judgment rather than replace it,” Geraghty agrees. “Firms that succeed are those that pair technological fluency with emotional intelligence as this is essential to the next generation of leadership.” [...] Whether through partnership or acquisition, both approaches point to the same truth. “Private markets are where much of the innovation is happening,” Niamh observes, “but they require a different kind of resilience.”\n\nWhen the conversation pivots to artificial intelligence, all three agree that its potential is enormous, but so are the responsibilities that come with it.\n\n“Of course, AI is really important,” Prendergast points out, “but it comes with significant considerations: regulatory compliance, legal considerations, data privacy, confidentiality. We also have to consider third-party oversight, and ethics and ensure our people feel empowered to use these tools responsibly.” [...] deloitte_logo\ndeloitte_logo\n\n### Together makes progress\n\n### Our history\n\n### Together makes progress\n\n### Our history\n\n### Together makes progress\n\n### Our history\n\n### Together makes progress\n\n### Our history\n\n### Together makes progress\n\n### Our history\n\n### Together makes progress\n\n### Our history\n\n### Together makes progress\n\n### Our history\n\n### Generative AI services\n\n### Operate services\n\n### Generative AI services\n\n### Operate services\n\n### Generative AI services\n\n### Operate services\n\n### Generative AI services\n\n### Operate services\n\n### Future of Advice Blog\n\n### Deloitte AI Institute Luxembourg\n\n### Future of Advice Blog\n\n### Deloitte AI Institute Luxembourg\n\n### Future of Advice Blog\n\n### Deloitte AI Institute Luxembourg\n\n### Future of Advice Blog",

      "title": "ERP finance transformation and internal controls in FSI",
      "content": "Leveraging ERP system accelerator and AI technology to develop intelligent controls boosts efficiency and confidence that risks are addressed. Generative AI, autonomous agents, robotic process automation (RPA), and machine learning can strategically update accounting, IT, governance, and operational controls. Examples include intelligent access and segregation controls, real-time integration monitoring, audit and SOX readiness, machine learning for risk assessment and predictive analytics, and ongoing improvement via AI-driven feedback and insights.\n\n##### Consequences of inadequate controls [...] Ironically, the same technologies that can reduce risk—digital transactions, AI, and cloud computing—can also introduce new and sometimes unforeseen vulnerabilities. With the rapid rise of cloud computing, more FSI organizations are migrating on-premises ERP systems to the cloud.1 In the process, they may face challenges specific to the cloud and cloud migration process. A recent Forbes survey found that 31% of financial services firms worldwide are concerned about cybersecurity threats from cloud-based sources.2 [...] ##### Keeping pace with rising FSI industry challenges\n\nToday’s financial services organizations face increasing pressure to modernize their ERP technology stacks in response to shifting industry demands—including evolving consumer preferences, rapid product innovation using AI and blockchain, and heightened regulatory scrutiny. Banks now accommodate stablecoin payments and deposits, wealth managers use AI for asset management, real estate firms are starting to offer fractional property investments via tokenization, and insurers are leveraging AI for both fraud detection and fee-based risk management.",

      "url": "http://mckinsey.com/capabilities/tech-and-ai/our-insights/superagency-in-the-workplace-empowering-people-to-unlock-ais-full-potential-at-work",
      "title": "AI in the workplace: A report for 2025 | McKinsey",
      "content": "Even those with a skeptical take on AI are familiar with it; 94 percent of Gloomers and 71 percent of Doomers say they have some familiarity with gen AI tools. Furthermore, approximately 80 percent of Gloomers and about half of Doomers say they are comfortable using gen AI at work.\n\nExhibit \n\nImage 8: Employee segments differ, but all indicate a high familiarity with gen AI.\n\nImage descriptions begins:\n\nThe exhibit depicts US employee sentiment toward gen AI, categorized into four archetypes: Doomer, Gloomer, Bloomer, and Zoomer. Each archetype's perspective is presented through a series of semicircular sunray charts showing the share of respondents within each group holding specific views. [...] Image description ends.\n\n### Leaders can invest more in their employees\n\nShare\n\nSidebar\n\nWho is using AI at work? Nearly everyone, even skeptical employees\n\nOur research looked at people who self-identify as “Zoomers,” “Bloomers,” “Gloomers,” and “Doomers” in their attitudes toward AI—a set of archetypes introduced in _Superagency_. We find that 39 percent of employees identify as Bloomers, who are AI optimists that want to collaborate with their companies to create responsible solutions. Meanwhile, 37 percent identify as Gloomers, who are more skeptical about AI and want extensive top-down AI regulations; 20 percent identify as Zoomers, who want AI to be quickly deployed with few guardrails; and just 4 percent identify as Doomers, who have a fundamentally negative view of AI (exhibit). [...] Image description ends.\n\nSidebar\n\nGlobal perspectives on training\n\nTo get a clearer picture of global AI adoption trends, we looked at trends across five countries: Australia, India, New Zealand, Singapore, and the United Kingdom. Broadly speaking, these employees and C-suite leaders—the “international” group in this report—have similar views of AI as their US peers. In some key areas, however, including the topic of training, their experiences differ.",
      "score": 0.15529642,

      "url": "https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/Industries/government-public/perspectives/cancer-knows-no-boundaries.html",
      "title": "Cancer Knows No Boundaries",
      "content": "deloitte_logo\ndeloitte_logo\n\n### Blockchain & Digital Assets\n\n### Blockchain & Digital Assets\n\n### Blockchain & Digital Assets\n\n### Blockchain & Digital Assets\n\n### Blockchain & Digital Assets\n\nSelect your location\n\nNo results found\n\nIf we have selected the wrong experience for you, please change it above.\n\n# Cancer knows no boundaries\n\nHow a new AI coalition is rewriting the rules of cancer research\n\nCancer does not respect institutions, sectors, borders, or timelines. It moves freely across families, communities, and generations. Yet for decades, the science fighting cancer has been constrained by silos. Data locked inside institutions. Research slowed by privacy barriers. Breakthroughs limited by the inability to see across the full landscape of disease. [...] By connecting data across institutions:\n\nThe long-term ambition extends even further. The goal is not only better treatment, but earlier detection and true prevention, enabled by large-scale pattern recognition across populations.\n\nThis is how discovery begins to move upstream.\n\nThe work no one sees, but everyone depends on\n\nOne of the most important truths about transformation is this. It is built on foundations that rarely make headlines.\n\nCommon data models. Governance frameworks. Security architectures. Regulatory approvals. Executive sign-offs. Hundreds of people aligned across multiple institutions.  \n  \nThis is slow, meticulous, unglamorous work. It is also the work that makes everything else possible. [...] At the heart of this effort is federated learning, a privacy-preserving approach to artificial intelligence that allows institutions to collaborate without ever sharing raw patient data.\n\nInstead of moving sensitive data into a centralized system, each cancer center keeps full control of its data within its own secure environment. AI models train locally. Only encrypted model insights move across the network.  \n  \nThis can preserve:\n\nAt the same time, it can unlock shared intelligence across institutions that would otherwise never be possible.\n\nThis is not simply a technical advance. It is a trust architecture. And trust is what makes scale possible.\n\nFrom isolated projects to a shared innovation engine",

      "title": "ERP finance transformation and internal controls in FSI",
      "content": "##### Keeping pace with rising FSI industry challenges\n\nToday’s financial services organizations face increasing pressure to modernize their ERP technology stacks in response to shifting industry demands—including evolving consumer preferences, rapid product innovation using AI and blockchain, and heightened regulatory scrutiny. Banks now accommodate stablecoin payments and deposits, wealth managers use AI for asset management, real estate firms are starting to offer fractional property investments via tokenization, and insurers are leveraging AI for both fraud detection and fee-based risk management. [...] Leveraging ERP system accelerator and AI technology to develop intelligent controls boosts efficiency and confidence that risks are addressed. Generative AI, autonomous agents, robotic process automation (RPA), and machine learning can strategically update accounting, IT, governance, and operational controls. Examples include intelligent access and segregation controls, real-time integration monitoring, audit and SOX readiness, machine learning for risk assessment and predictive analytics, and ongoing improvement via AI-driven feedback and insights.\n\n##### Consequences of inadequate controls [...] Ironically, the same technologies that can reduce risk—digital transactions, AI, and cloud computing—can also introduce new and sometimes unforeseen vulnerabilities. With the rapid rise of cloud computing, more FSI organizations are migrating on-premises ERP systems to the cloud.1 In the process, they may face challenges specific to the cloud and cloud migration process. A recent Forbes survey found that 31% of financial services firms worldwide are concerned about cybersecurity threats from cloud-based sources.2",
